revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Calthorpe as a Flag Officer.JPG]] → [[File:Somerset Gough-Calthorpe as a flag officer.jpg]] this is not Mena Calthorpe
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name= Sir Somerset Gough-Calthorpe |image= Somerset Gough-Calthorpe as a flag officer.jpg |caption= Sir Somerset Gough-Calthorpe |birth_date= 23 December 1865 |death_date= {{death-date and age|27 July 1937|23 December 1865}} |birth_place= [[London]], England |death_place= [[Ryde]], [[Isle of Wight]] |nickname= |allegiance= United Kingdom |branch= [[Royal Navy]] |serviceyears= 1878–1930 |rank= [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] |unit= |commands= [[Commander-in-Chief, Portsmouth|Portsmouth Command]]
[[Mediterranean Fleet]]
Coastguard and Reserves
2nd Cruiser Squadron
{{HMS|Dreadnought|1906|6}}
{{HMS|Hindustan|1903|6}}
{{HMS|Roxburgh|1904|6}}
{{HMS|Pandora|1900|6}}
{{HMS|Halcyon|1894|6}} |battles= [[Anglo-Ashanti wars|Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War]]
[[First World War]] |awards= [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]]
[[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of St Michael and St George]]
[[Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] |laterwork= }} [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] '''Sir Somerset Arthur Gough-Calthorpe''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GCB|GCMG|CVO}} (23 December 1865 – 27 July 1937), sometimes known as '''Sir Somerset Calthorpe''', was a [[Royal Navy]] officer and a member of the [[Gough-Calthorpe family]]. After serving as a junior officer during the [[Anglo-Ashanti wars|Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War]], he became naval [[attaché]] observing the actions of the [[Imperial Russian Navy]] during the [[Russo-Japanese War]] and then went on to command an armoured cruiser and then a battleship during the early years of the 20th century. During the [[First World War]] Gough-Calthorpe initially served as commander of the 2nd Cruiser Squadron of the [[Grand Fleet]], then became [[Second Sea Lord]] and after that became Admiral commanding the Coastguard and Reserves. In the closing years of the War he served as Commander-in-Chief of the [[Mediterranean Fleet]], in which capacity he signed the [[Armistice of Mudros]] on behalf of all the Allies, by which the [[Ottoman Empire]] accepted defeat and ceased hostilities. The [[Occupation of Constantinople]] began with the Allied fleet entering [[Constantinople]] in November 1918 and it was Gough-Calthorpe's flagship, {{HMS|Superb|1907|6}}, that led the way. After the War Gough-Calthorpe served as British Commissioner in the Ottoman Empire during a time of considerable political instability associated with the [[partitioning of the Ottoman Empire]] and the [[allied intervention in the Russian Civil War]]. ==Naval career== ===Early career=== Born the son of Lieutenant-General [[Somerset Gough-Calthorpe, 7th Baron Calthorpe]], by his marriage to Eliza Maria Chamier,{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/32253?docPos=1|title=Somerset Gough-Calthorpe|publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|accessdate=26 October 2014}} Gough-Calthorpe joined the Royal Navy as a [[cadet]] in the training ship [[HMS Prince of Wales (1860)|HMS ''Britannia'']] on 15 January 1878.Heathcote, p. 103 Promoted to [[midshipman]] on 19 March 1880, he was appointed to the [[armored cruiser|armoured cruiser]] [[HMS Northampton (1876)|HMS ''Northampton'']], flagship of the [[North America and West Indies Station]] later that year. Promoted to [[sub-lieutenant]] on 19 March 1884, he joined the [[corvette]] [[HMS Rover (1874)|HMS ''Rover'']] in the Training Squadron in September 1885 and, after further promotion to [[lieutenant (Royal Navy)|lieutenant]] on 19 March 1886, he transferred to the [[battleship]] [[HMS Colossus (1882)|HMS ''Colossus'']] in June 1886. After attending the torpedo school [[HMS Vernon (shore establishment)|HMS ''Vernon'']], he joined the directing staff there in 1890 and was then in August 1891 was deployed to [[Hong Kong]] on torpedo duties, before rejoining the directing staff at HMS ''Vernon'' in January 1894. He became torpedo officer in the cruiser [[HMS St George (1892)|HMS St ''George'']] on the [[Cape of Good Hope Station|Cape of Good Hope and West Coast of Africa Station]] in October 1894 and saw action with [[naval brigade]]s during the [[Anglo-Ashanti wars|Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War]]. Promoted to [[commander]] on 1 January 1896,{{LondonGazette|issue=26696|date=3 January 1896|supp=|startpage=4|accessdate=26 October 2014}} Gough-Calthorpe became Executive Officer in the armoured cruiser [[HMS Imperieuse (1883)|HMS ''Imperieuse'']], flagship of the [[Pacific Station]], in March 1896.Heathcote, p. 104 After another tour at HMS ''Vernon'', he became commanding officer of the [[torpedo gunboat]] [[HMS Halcyon (1894)|HMS ''Halcyon'']] in the [[Mediterranean Fleet]] in September 1900. He went on to be commanding officer of the cruiser [[HMS Pandora (1900)|HMS ''Pandora'']] during propeller trials at [[HMNB Portsmouth|Portsmouth]] in July 1901,{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Naval & Military intelligence|day_of_week=Friday |date=6 September 1901 |page_number=8 |issue=36553| }} and, having been promoted to [[Captain (Royal Navy)|captain]] on 1 January 1902{{LondonGazette|issue=27393|date=3 January 1902|supp=|startpage=3|accessdate=26 October 2014}} and having attended a course at the [[Royal Naval College, Greenwich]],{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Naval & Military intelligence |day_of_week=Monday |date=6 January 1902 |page_number=8 |issue=36657| }} he became naval [[attaché]] observing the actions of the [[Imperial Russian Navy]] during the [[Russo-Japanese War]].{{cite web|last=Rickard|first= J. |year=2007|url=http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/people_gough_calthorpe.html|title= Somerset Arthur Gough-Calthorpe|accessdate=26 October 2014}} He became commanding officer of the armoured cruiser [[HMS Roxburgh (1904)|HMS ''Roxburgh'']] in November 1905 and then, having been appointed a [[Member of the Royal Victorian Order]] on 25 September 1906,{{LondonGazette|issue=27960|date=23 October 1906|supp=|startpage=7108|accessdate=26 October 2014}} he became commanding officer of the battleship [[HMS Hindustan (1903)|HMS ''Hindustan'']] in December 1907. He then became Captain of the Fleet for the [[Home Fleet]] in the battleship [[HMS Dreadnought (1906)|HMS ''Dreadnought'']] in December 1909. He was advanced to [[Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] on 2 August 1910.{{LondonGazette|issue=28403|date=2 August 1910|supp=|startpage=5581|accessdate=26 October 2014}} Promoted to [[rear admiral]] on 27 August 1911{{LondonGazette|issue=28526|date=29 August 1911|supp=|startpage=6373|accessdate=26 October 2014}} and, having been appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] on 27 September 1912,{{LondonGazette|issue=28648|date=27 September 1912|supp=|startpage=7107|accessdate=26 October 2014}} he became second-in-command of the [[1st Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|1st Battle Squadron]], with his flag in the battleship [[HMS St. Vincent (1908)|HMS St ''Vincent'']], in December 1912. ===First World War=== [[File:HMS Superb 1917 IWM SP 002744.jpg|thumb|left|The Battleship, {{HMS|Superb|1907|6}}, which, as Gough-Calthorpe's flagship, led the Allied fleet that steamed into [[Constantinople]] in November 1918]] Gough-Calthorpe became commander of the 2nd Cruiser Squadron of the [[Grand Fleet]], with his flag in the armoured cruiser [[HMS Shannon (1906)|HMS ''Shannon'']], in July 1914 on the outbreak of the [[World War I|First World War]]. Advanced to [[Order of the Bath|Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] on 1 January 1916,{{LondonGazette|issue=29423|supp=yes|startpage=80|date=31 December 1915|accessdate=26 October 2014}} he became [[Second Sea Lord]] in July 1916 and Admiral commanding the Coastguard and Reserves in December 1916. Promoted to [[vice-admiral]] on 26 April 1917,{{LondonGazette|issue=30037|supp=|startpage=3955|date=27 April 1917|accessdate=26 October 2014}} he became [[Mediterranean Fleet|Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean Fleet]], with his flag in the battleship [[HMS Superb (1907)|HMS ''Superb'']], in July 1917. In that capacity he established a complex convoy system to protect British and allied shipping at sea in the Mediterranean from attack by enemy [[submarine]]s. [[File:Vice-admiral the Hon Sir Somerset A. Gough-calthorpe, Gcmg, Kcb, Cvo on Board 'hms Superb' at Constantinople, 1918 Art.IWMART2494.jpg|thumb|upright|right| Portrait by [[Philip Connard]] of Gough-Calthorpe on board HMS ''Superb'' at Constantinople in November 1918]] He went on to sign the [[Armistice of Mudros]] on behalf of all the Allies on 30 October 1918, by which the [[Ottoman Empire]] accepted defeat and ceased hostilities. [[Georges Clemenceau]], [[Prime Minister of France]], complained that Admiral [[Dominique-Marie Gauchet]] had not been present at the treaty signing but the British Government gave Gough-Calthorpe its full backing. When the Allied fleet steamed into [[Constantinople]] in November 1918, it was Gough-Calthorpe's flagship, HMS ''Superb'', that led the way. ===After the war=== Gough-Calthorpe became British Commissioner in the [[Ottoman Empire]] at the end of the War during a time of considerable political instability associated with the [[partitioning of the Ottoman Empire]] and the [[allied intervention in the Russian Civil War]]. Appointed a [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of St Michael and St George]] on 1 January 1919{{LondonGazette|issue=31099|date=31 December 1918|supp=yes|startpage=109|accessdate=26 October 2014}} and promoted to full [[admiral]] on 31 July 1919,{{LondonGazette|issue=31489|date=5 August 1919|supp=|startpage=9961|accessdate=26 October 2014}} he became [[Commander-in-Chief, Portsmouth]] in April 1920.Heathcote, p. 105 He also became naval representative to the Permanent Armaments Commission of the [[League of Nations]] in July 1920.{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1920/jul/05/armaments-permament-commission|title=Armaments (Permanent Commission)|publisher=Hansard|date=5 July 1920|accessdate=26 October 2014}} Gough-Calthorpe was advanced to [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] on 3 June 1922,{{LondonGazette|issue=32716|date=2 June 1922|supp=yes|startpage=4321|accessdate=26 October 2014}} appointed a [[Deputy Lieutenant]] for the [[Isle of Wight]] on 14 February 1924{{LondonGazette|issue=32910|date=22 February 1924|supp=|startpage=1574|accessdate=26 October 2014}} and appointed [[List of First and Principal Naval Aides-de-Camp|First and Principal Naval Aide-de-Camp]] to [[George V|the King]] on 31 July 1924.{{LondonGazette|issue=32962|date=5 August 1924|supp=|startpage=5889|accessdate=26 October 2014}} Promoted to [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] on 8 May 1925,{{LondonGazette|issue=33049|date=22 May 1925|supp=|startpage=3445|accessdate=26 October 2014}} he retired in May 1930 and, having been appointed a Deputy Lieutenant for [[Southampton]] on 26 March 1932,{{LondonGazette|issue=33813|date=1 April 1932|supp=|startpage=2144|accessdate=26 October 2014}} died at his home in [[Ryde]] on the Isle of Wight on 27 July 1937. ==Family== [[File:Mrs Effie Calthorpe.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Mrs. Effie Calthorpe née Dunsmuir]] Gough-Calthorpe married Effie Dunsmuir, daughter of Hon. [[Robert Dunsmuir]], of [[Craigdarroch Castle]], [[Victoria, British Columbia]], and his wife, Joanna, daughter of Alexander White, of [[Kilmarnock]], Scotland at [[St George's, Hanover Square]] in London in March 1900.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/typesofcanadianw01morguoft|last=Morgan|first=Henry James|title= Types of Canadian women and of women who are or have been connected with Canada|publisher=Toronto|year= 1903|accessdate=26 October 2014}} They had no children. ==Honours and awards== *[[Order of the Bath|Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] – 3 June 1922 (KCB – 1 January 1916; CB – 27 September 1912) *[[Order of St Michael and St George|Knight Grand Cross of the Order of St Michael and St George]] – 1 January 1919 *[[Royal Victorian Order|Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] – 2 August 1910 (MVO – 25 September 1906) *Grand Officer of the [[Legion of Honour]] (France) – 12 December 1918{{LondonGazette|issue=31063|supp=yes|startpage=14685|date=10 December 1918|accessdate=26 October 2014}} *[[Medal of Military Merit (Greece)|Medal of Military Merit]] (Greece) – 16 September 1919{{LondonGazette|issue=31553|supp=yes|startpage=11583|date=12 September 1919|accessdate=26 October 2014}} *Grand Officer of the [[Order of Saints Maurice and Lazarus]] (Italy) – 6 April 1918{{LondonGazette|issue=30616|supp=yes|startpage=4264|date=5 April 1918|accessdate=26 October 2014}} *Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Redeemer]] (Greece) – 24 May 1919{{LondonGazette|issue=31354|supp=yes|startpage=6449|date=23 May 1919|accessdate=26 October 2014}} *Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Crown of Italy]] (Italy) – 16 September 1919{{LondonGazette|issue=31553|supp=yes|startpage=11582|date=12 September 1919|accessdate=26 October 2014}} ==See also== *[[Armistice of Mudros]] *[[Occupation of Istanbul]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== * {{cite book|last=Heathcote |first=Tony |title=The British Admirals of the Fleet 1734 – 1995
